EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

Helix Water District has established a risk management plan according to Federal EPA's (40 CFR Part 68) and California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) regulations to enhance already existing safety and emergency response programs.  Helix Water District is extremely cautious in the handling of all chemicals and is very dilligent about safety for its employees, the communities where its facilities are located, and customers.  Helix Water District staff is well trained and utilizes modern equipment to monitor its facilities to provide safeguards, while effectively employing these useful chemicals.  These chemicals play an important role in water treatment, enabling everyone to lead healthier lives.  

 

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Chlorine is injected into the water in order to disinfect it and to prevent bacterial growth while the water travels through pipelines. The maximum intended inventory for this facility is approximately 48,000 pounds of chlorine kept in 24 one-ton containers.  



HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary:

Scenario Description: Per the EPA Regulations, one worst-case release scenario has been defined for the Chlorination System.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  



Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary:

Scenario Description: Per the EPA Regulations, two alternative-case release scenario has been defined for the Chlorination System.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  



Risk Considerations:

Although the storage and use of chlorine has inherent potential risks and the release scenarios can potentially reach sensitive populations within the community, Helix Water District has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event unlikely.  In addition to the safety practices of the

facility and plant personnel to make the worst-case event unlikely, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.



In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a chlorine release.  Facility has a scrubber, rupture discs, and chlorine gas detection.  For protection of employees and responders, safety showers and respiratory equipment are available on site.



RISK MANAGEMENT PREVENTION PROGRAM

As part of the implementation of the RMP Program 3, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Helix Water District to manage process safety issues associated with the use of chlorine. Prevention Program 3 elements include:



A?68.65    Process Safety Information (PSI) 

A?68.67    Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

A?68.69 Operating Procedures (OP)

A?68.71    Training (TRN)

A?68.73    Mechanical Integrity (MI)

A?68.75    Management of Change (MOC)

A?68.77    Pre-Startup Review (PSSR)

A?68.79    Compliance Audits (CA)

A?68.81    Incident Investigation (II)

A?68.83    Employee Participation (EP)

A?68.85    Hot Work Permit (HWP)

A?68.87    Contractors (CO)

A?68.90    Emergency Planning & Response (EP&R)



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no RMP-applicable releases of chlorine at the facility in the previous five (5) years.  



FLAMMABLES: WORST CASE

The use of flammable materials at Helix Water District is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 



FLAMMABLES: ALTERNATIVE RELEASE

The use of flammable materials at Helix Water District is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Helix Water District has implemented an Emergency Response Program (ERP) to prepare for potential incidents, respond to them effectively, and recover from their impacts.  The ERP has included a set of potential incidents that are used for emergency drills, including accidental release of toxic gases.  Facility has HAZWOPER trained responders who are able to react to emergency situations.  Emergency training is provided annually to the emergency response team. The ERP meets Cal/OSHA 8 CCR 5192 and Cal/OSHA 8 CCR 3220.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Helix Water District is extremely diligent in the handling of chlorine and plans for improvements immediately if an issue arises.  Currently, there are no planned equipment modifications to improve safety.
